dictationText: 55 yo F with right shoulder pain x 3 weeks, worse with overhead activity. Rule out rotator cuff tear. Request MRI right shoulder without contrast.

validationResult.feedback: Initial radiographs should precede MRI for new shoulder pain per ACR guidelines. Consider X-ray first to rule out fracture, arthritis, or calcifications before proceeding to advanced imaging.

suggestedCPTCodes.description: Radiologic examination, shoulder; complete, minimum of two views
Magnetic resonance (eg, proton) imaging, any joint of upper extremity; without contrast material(s)

dictationText: 42-year-old male with severe headache for 2 days, no prior history of migraines. Experiencing nausea and photophobia. No focal neurological deficits. Request CT head without contrast to rule out intracranial pathology.

validationResult.feedback: CT head without contrast is appropriate for severe new-onset headache with nausea and photophobia to exclude emergent intracranial pathology. Consider MRI if CT is negative and symptoms persist.

suggestedCPTCodes.description: Computed tomography, head or brain; without contrast material

dictationText: 38-year-old female with RUQ abdominal pain, elevated liver enzymes. History of gallstones. No fever. Pain worse after meals. Request abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for cholecystitis.

validationResult.feedback: Abdominal ultrasound is the recommended first-line imaging for RUQ pain with elevated liver enzymes and history of gallstones. This non-invasive study can evaluate for gallbladder wall thickening, stones, biliary dilation, and liver parenchyma without radiation exposure.

suggestedICD10Codes.description: Calculus of gallbladder without cholecystitis without obstruction

dictationText: 62-year-old male with chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. History of COPD. No fever. Oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Request chest x-ray to evaluate for pneumonia or pneumothorax. STAT.

validationResult.feedback: Chest x-ray is an appropriate first-line imaging study for evaluating chest pain with shortness of breath, especially in a COPD patient with decreased oxygen saturation. STAT designation is justified given the clinical presentation.

suggestedCPTCodes.description: Radiologic examination, chest, two views, frontal and lateral

dictationText: 45-year-old female with lower back pain after lifting heavy object. No radicular symptoms. Request lumbar spine x-ray to evaluate for fracture or degenerative changes.

validationResult.feedback: Lumbar x-ray is appropriate for acute back pain after trauma to rule out fracture. No red flags or radicular symptoms noted that would warrant advanced imaging at initial presentation.

suggestedCPTCodes.description: Radiologic examination, spine, lumbosacral; anteroposterior and lateral views
